items.title: New Democrats vying for party's top job square off in final leadership debate
items.summary_auto: Five NDP leadership candidates have taken the stage in what will be the final debate before members decide who will land the party's top job.

items.title: Youth advocates call on Ottawa to listen to them before tabling new online harms bill
items.summary_auto: Youth advocates are calling on the federal government to treat online safety as a human-rights issue, saying current systems are "not supporting them."

items.title: Federal judge accuses Trump administration of 'terror' against immigrants, vacates ruling on mass detention
items.summary_auto: A U.S. federal judge has thrown out an administrative board's decision endorsing the Trump  administration's policy of subjecting thousands of people arrested during its immigration crackdown to mandatory detention.

items.title: What we know about the U.S. military buildup near Iran
items.summary_auto: The U.S. has deployed dozens of military aircraft and other assets to bases in and near the Middle East, with President Donald Trump suggesting Thursday strikes against Iran could begin “within 10 days” if a deal is not reached about its nuclear program.

items.title: Montreal hospital recognized for efforts to improve emergency care for seniors
items.summary_auto: The American College of Emergency Physicians is acknowledging St. Mary’s Hospital for its dedication to elder care — a first for a health facility in Montreal. Some of the criteria include how hospitals reduce the risks of infection, delirium and immobility.

items.title: The facts about Cuba in 60 seconds
items.summary_auto: Cuba is in crisis. The U.S. is blocking the country’s oil supply and Cubans are facing shortages of food, medicine and fuel. Here are the facts.

items.title: Banner with Trump's image displayed outside Justice Dept. headquarters
items.summary_auto: A large banner featuring Donald Trump's face was hung on the exterior of the U.S. Justice Department headquarters on Thursday in an apparent display of the Republican president's efforts to exert power over the law enforcement agency that once investigated him.

items.title: How to watch the final NDP leadership debate on CBC
items.summary_auto: Here's how you can tune into CBC's coverage of the final NDP leadership debate in New Westminster, B.C.

items.title: 4 extortion investigations launched in Vancouver — the first in the city
items.summary_auto: B.C.’s most populous city is now part of a growing trend of crime where perpetrators threaten residents and businesses with violence in exchange for money.

items.title: Destruction by Sudan's rebels in El Fasher bears 'hallmarks of genocide': UN experts
items.summary_auto: A "campaign of destruction" in October by Sudanese paramilitary forces against non-Arab communities in and near a city in the western region of Darfur shows "hallmarks of genocide," UN-backed human rights experts said Thursday, a dramatic finding in the country's devastating war.

items.title: Trump hosts 1st Board of Peace meeting, announces pledges for reconstruction-peacekeeper funding for Gaza
items.summary_auto: Five countries have committed ‌troops for an international security force for Gaza and U.S. President Donald Trump promised billions of dollars for reconstruction of the war-torn territory, on Thursday during the first meeting of his fledgling Board of Peace.

items.title: Canadian Challenge mushers race in Saskatchewan’s biggest dog sled event
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Challenge is the biggest dog sled race in Saskatchewan. The multi-day competition based in La Ronge boils down to a musher, a team of dogs and a winter trail that has carried people through the North for generations.

items.title: Best thing since sliced bread? Japan's viral 7-Eleven egg salad sandwich is coming to Canada
items.summary_auto: Japan's ubiquitous convenience store sandwiches have a cult-like following, and its 7-Eleven stores are described as a national treasure. Now, its crown jewel is coming to Canada: the tamago sando.

items.title: 'Enough is enough': Canadian intelligence experts to focus on extortion crime, federal minister says
items.summary_auto: The federal finance minister visited Mississauga, Ont., Thursday to announce dedicated financial intelligence experts who will focus on extortion crime targeting Canadian businesses and households.

items.title: South Korean shipbuilding giant announces major boost for Ontario marine industry at Hamilton site
items.summary_auto: A new partnership will see South Korean company Hanwha Ocean share resources and knowledge with Ontario Shipyards and a new shipbuilding learning hub for Mohawk College students.

items.title: Pneumonia hospitalizations in Canada rose dramatically last respiratory illness season, CIHI says
items.summary_auto: Newly released data backs up what hospitals were experiencing during the last respiratory illness season: A big rise in the number of people being treated for pneumonia. The Canadian Institute for Health Information says children between five and 17 years old were especially hard hit.

items.title: Sarah McLachlan, Allison Russell and Cameron Whitcomb to perform at the 2026 Juno Awards
items.summary_auto: McLachlan and Russell will perform a special tribute to Lifetime Achievement Award recipient Joni Mitchell.

items.title: 'Like lamb to a slaughter': Woman tells court details of alleged sexual assault by Frank Stronach
items.summary_auto: A woman said it's hard to live with the fact that she may have walked "like lamb to a slaughter" into a Toronto condo bedroom where she was then sexually assaulted by Frank Stronach, court heard on Thursday.

items.title: Grandson of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups inventor accuses Hershey of recipe changes
items.summary_auto: The grandson of the inventor of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups has lashed out at The Hershey Co., accusing the candy company of hurting the Reese's brand by shifting to cheaper ingredients in many products.

items.title: Message from her match was 'like a robot had sent it.' How AI is changing dating apps
items.summary_auto:
Sometimes when Nikita Kokal scrolls through a dating app, she'll match with someone solely to ask if they used artificial
intelligence to craft their profile. She sees it all the time, she says.

items.title: Trump warns Iran to make a nuclear deal or 'bad things' will happen
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump warned Iran on Thursday that it must reach a deal over its nuclear program or "bad things" will happen, and appeared to set a 10-day deadline before the U.S. might take action.

items.title: Emotional support chicken comforts B.C. researcher studying pets across cultures
items.summary_auto: A researcher from the University of Northern British Columbia, assisted by her pet chicken, is conducting an international study on the social and emotional impact of pets on youth across cultures.

items.title: Independent review says dog testing at London, Ont. hospital done ethically, but flags communication gaps
items.summary_auto: A third-party review into the use of dogs for medical research at London's Lawson Research Institute has found that the testing, which induced heart attacks in the dogs, followed all "regulatory, ethical and professional standards."

items.title: Northeast B.C. is ‘one big family’ supporting Tumbler Ridge, says district chair
items.summary_auto: There's been an outpouring of support across the country, but Peace River Regional District chair Brad Sperling says you can tell how close everyone is in the northeast by looking at what's being said and done locally.

items.title: Indigenous artist slams Ontario premier's basket weaving comments
Canadian coach won't rule Sidney Crosby out of Olympic semifinal
items.summary_auto: Canada coach Jon Cooper has not ruled out captain Sidney Crosby for Friday's semifinal against Finland at the Milano-Cortina Olympics.

items.title: Canada's curling men advance to Olympic gold-medal game, defeating Norway in extra end
items.summary_auto: Skip Brad Jacobs and his Calgary-based rink will play for an Olympic gold medal on Saturday against Great Britain after a 5-4 semifinal win over Norway on Thursday night in Italy.

items.title: Lawyer who fought against mandatory oath reacts to Alberta seeking Supreme Court ruling
items.summary_auto: The Alberta government wants the Supreme Court of Canada to decide the constitutionality of a rule requiring new lawyers to swear an oath of allegiance to the monarch. In December, Alberta's Court of Appeal sided with Sikh lawyer Prabjot Singh Wirring, who has been fighting the mandatory requirement since June 2022.

items.title: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor photographed leaving police station in the back of a car after his arrest
Couple living on small pension told they don't qualify for grant to help son move home
items.summary_auto: Christian Herridge has spent more than 16 months in hospital, but is determined to move back home to his parents’ house in Mahone Bay, N.S.

items.title: N.S. politicians prepare for the legislature's spring session — and an opening day budget
items.summary_auto: MLAs are scheduled to return to the Nova Scotia Legislature for the spring session on Monday and sources tell CBC News that Finance Minister John Lohr is expected to table his budget that same day.

items.title: South Korea's ex-president Yoon receives life sentence for imposing martial law
items.summary_auto: Yoon Suk Yeol fell from office after an ill-advised attempt to overcome an opposition-controlled legislature by declaring martial law and sending troops to surround the legislature on Dec. 3, 2024.

items.title: Non-binary client wins discrimination case against Montreal-area hair salon
items.summary_auto: Quebec's Human Rights Tribunal has ordered a Montreal-area hair salon to pay $500 in damages to a non-binary person. The individual filed a complaint because they were forced to choose between booking either a men's or a women's haircut.

items.title: B.C. First Nation hopes for reconciliation as contentious land claim heads to appeal
items.summary_auto: B.C. is in "untested waters" according to one lawyer after a trial, with evidence spanning centuries, granted Aboriginal title to some privately held land in B.C. The decision has stirred divisive debate in the province around reconciliation and its legal commitments to First Nations.
